Events.html: 406 – Vandals, Alans and Suebians cross the Rhine, beginning an invasion of Gaul.
Events.text: Vandals, Alans and Suebians cross the Rhine, beginning an invasion of Gaul.

Events.html: 535 – Byzantine general Belisarius completes the conquest of Sicily, defeating the Gothic garrison of Palermo (Panormos), and ending his consulship for the year.
Events.text: Byzantine general Belisarius completes the conquest of Sicily, defeating the Gothic garrison of Palermo (Panormos), and ending his consulship for the year.

Events.html: 1225 – The Lý Dynasty of Vietnam ends after 216 years by the enthronement of the boy emperor Trần Thái Tông, husband of the last Lý monarch, Lý Chiêu Hoàng, starting the Trần Dynasty.
Events.text: The Lý Dynasty of Vietnam ends after 216 years by the enthronement of the boy emperor Trần Thái Tông, husband of the last Lý monarch, Lý Chiêu Hoàng, starting the Trần Dynasty.

Events.html: 1229 – James I of Aragon the Conqueror enters Medina Mayurqa (now known as Palma, Spain) thus consummating the Christian reconquest of the island of Majorca.
Events.text: James I of Aragon the Conqueror enters Medina Mayurqa (now known as Palma, Spain) thus consummating the Christian reconquest of the island of Majorca.

Events.html: 1501 – The First Battle of Cannanore commences.
Events.text: The First Battle of Cannanore commences.

Events.html: 1600 – The British East India Company is chartered.
Events.text: The British East India Company is chartered.

Events.html: 1660 – James II of England is named Duke of Normandy by Louis XIV of France.
Events.text: James II of England is named Duke of Normandy by Louis XIV of France.

Events.html: 1687 – The first Huguenots set sail from France to the Cape of Good Hope.
Events.text: The first Huguenots set sail from France to the Cape of Good Hope.

Events.html: 1695 – A window tax is imposed in England, causing many householders to brick up windows to avoid the tax.
Events.text: A window tax is imposed in England, causing many householders to brick up windows to avoid the tax.

Events.html: 1757 – Empress Elizabeth I of Russia issues her ukase incorporating Königsberg into Russia.
Events.text: Empress Elizabeth I of Russia issues her ukase incorporating Königsberg into Russia.

Events.html: 1759 – Arthur Guinness signs a 9,000 year lease at £45 per annum and starts brewing Guinness.
Events.text: Arthur Guinness signs a 9,000 year lease at £45 per annum and starts brewing Guinness.

Events.html: 1775 – American Revolutionary War: Battle of Quebec: British forces repulse an attack by Continental Army General Richard Montgomery.
Events.text: American Revolutionary War: Battle of Quebec: British forces repulse an attack by Continental Army General Richard Montgomery.

Events.html: 1790 – Efimeris, the oldest Greek newspaper of which issues have survived till today is published for the first time.
Events.text: Efimeris, the oldest Greek newspaper of which issues have survived till today is published for the first time.

Events.html: 1796 – The incorporation of Baltimore as a city.
Events.text: The incorporation of Baltimore as a city.

Events.html: 1831 – Gramercy Park is deeded to New York, New York.
Events.text: Gramercy Park is deeded to New York, New York.

Events.html: 1853 – A dinner party is held inside a life-size model of an Iguanodon created by Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins and Sir Richard Owen in south London, England.
Events.text: A dinner party is held inside a life-size model of an Iguanodon created by Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins and Sir Richard Owen in south London, England.

Events.html: 1857 – Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa, then a small logging town, as the capital of Canada.
Events.text: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa, then a small logging town, as the capital of Canada.

Events.html: 1862 – American Civil War: Abraham Lincoln signs an act that admits West Virginia to the Union, thus dividing Virginia in two.
Events.text: American Civil War: Abraham Lincoln signs an act that admits West Virginia to the Union, thus dividing Virginia in two.

Events.html: 1862 – American Civil War: The Battle of Stones River begins near Murfreesboro, Tennessee.
Events.text: American Civil War: The Battle of Stones River begins near Murfreesboro, Tennessee.

Events.html: 1878 – Karl Benz, working in Mannheim, Germany, filed for a patent on his first reliable two-stroke gas engine, and he was granted the patent in 1879.
Events.text: Karl Benz, working in Mannheim, Germany, filed for a patent on his first reliable two-stroke gas engine, and he was granted the patent in 1879.

Events.html: 1879 – Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time, in Menlo Park, New Jersey.
Events.text: Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time, in Menlo Park, New Jersey.

Events.html: 1906 – Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar signs the Persian Constitution of 1906.
Events.text: Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar signs the Persian Constitution of 1906.

Events.html: 1907 – The first New Year's Eve celebration is held in Times Square (then known as Longacre Square) in New York, New York.
Events.text: The first New Year's Eve celebration is held in Times Square (then known as Longacre Square) in New York, New York.

Events.html: 1909 – Manhattan Bridge opens.
Events.text: Manhattan Bridge opens.

Events.html: 1923 – The chimes of Big Ben are broadcast on radio for the first time by the BBC.
Events.text: The chimes of Big Ben are broadcast on radio for the first time by the BBC.

Events.html: 1944 – World War II: Hungary declares war on Nazi Germany.
Events.text: World War II: Hungary declares war on Nazi Germany.

Events.html: 1944 – World War II: Operation Nordwind, the last major German offensive on the Western Front begins.
Events.text: World War II: Operation Nordwind, the last major German offensive on the Western Front begins.

Events.html: 1946 – President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of hostilities in World War II.
Events.text: President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of hostilities in World War II.

Events.html: 1951 – The Marshall Plan expires after distributing more than US$13.3 billion in foreign aid to rebuild Europe.
Events.text: The Marshall Plan expires after distributing more than US$13.3 billion in foreign aid to rebuild Europe.

Events.html: 1955 – General Motors becomes the first U.S. corporation to make over US$1 billion in a year.
Events.text: General Motors becomes the first U.S. corporation to make over US$1 billion in a year.

Events.html: 1960 – The farthing coin ceases to be legal tender in the United Kingdom.
Events.text: The farthing coin ceases to be legal tender in the United Kingdom.

Events.html: 1961 – RTÉ, Ireland's state broadcaster, launches its first national television service.
Events.text: RTÉ, Ireland's state broadcaster, launches its first national television service.

Events.html: 1963 – The Central African Federation officially collapses, subsequently becoming Zambia, Malawi and Rhodesia.
Events.text: The Central African Federation officially collapses, subsequently becoming Zambia, Malawi and Rhodesia.

Events.html: 1965 – Jean-Bédel Bokassa, leader of the Central African Republic army, and his military officers begins a coup d'état against the government of President David Dacko.
Events.text: Jean-Bédel Bokassa, leader of the Central African Republic army, and his military officers begins a coup d'état against the government of President David Dacko.

links.subject: President
links.title: List of heads of state of the Central African Republic and Central African Empire

Events.html: 1967 – The Youth International Party, popularly known as the "Yippies", is founded.
Events.text: The Youth International Party, popularly known as the "Yippies", is founded.

Events.html: 1981 – A coup d'état in Ghana removes President Hilla Limann's PNP government and replaces it with the Provisional National Defence Council led by Flight lieutenant Jerry Rawlings.
Events.text: A coup d'état in Ghana removes President Hilla Limann's PNP government and replaces it with the Provisional National Defence Council led by Flight lieutenant Jerry Rawlings.

links.subject: President
links.title: List of heads of state of Ghana

Events.html: 1983 – The AT&T Bell System is broken up by the United States Government.
Events.text: The AT&T Bell System is broken up by the United States Government.

Events.html: 1983 – In Nigeria a coup d'état led by Major General Muhammadu Buhari ends the Second Nigerian Republic.
Events.text: In Nigeria a coup d'état led by Major General Muhammadu Buhari ends the Second Nigerian Republic.

Events.html: 1986 – A fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, kills 97 and injures 140.
Events.text: A fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, kills 97 and injures 140.

links.subject: fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel
links.title: Dupont Plaza Hotel arson

Events.html: 1988 – Pittsburgh Penguins' Mario Lemieux becomes the only National Hockey League player to score goals in five different ways: even strength, shorthanded, power play, penalty shot, and empty net, during an 8–6 win over the New Jersey Devils.
Events.text: Pittsburgh Penguins' Mario Lemieux becomes the only National Hockey League player to score goals in five different ways: even strength, shorthanded, power play, penalty shot, and empty net, during an 8–6 win over the New Jersey Devils.

Events.html: 1988 – First Winter Ascent of Lhotse (8,516m) by Krzysztof Wielicki (solo).
Events.text: First Winter Ascent of Lhotse (8,516m) by Krzysztof Wielicki (solo).

Events.html: 1991 – All official Soviet Union institutions have ceased operations by this date and the Soviet Union is officially dissolved.
Events.text: All official Soviet Union institutions have ceased operations by this date and the Soviet Union is officially dissolved.

Events.html: 1992 – Czechoslovakia is peacefully dissolved in what is dubbed by media as the Velvet Divorce, resulting in the creation of the Czech Republic and Slovakia.
Events.text: Czechoslovakia is peacefully dissolved in what is dubbed by media as the Velvet Divorce, resulting in the creation of the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

Events.html: 1994 – This date is skipped altogether in Kiribati as the Phoenix Islands and Line Islands change time zones from UTC−11:00 to UTC+13:00 and UTC−10:00 to UTC+14:00, respectively.
Events.text: This date is skipped altogether in Kiribati as the Phoenix Islands and Line Islands change time zones from UTC−11:00 to UTC+13:00 and UTC−10:00 to UTC+14:00, respectively.

Events.html: 1994 – The First Chechen War: Russian army began a New Year's storm of Grozny.
Events.text: The First Chechen War: Russian army began a New Year's storm of Grozny.

Events.year: 1998– The European Exchange Rate Mechanism freezes the values of the legacy currencies in the Eurozone, and establishes the value of the euro currency.
Events.html: 1998– The European Exchange Rate Mechanism freezes the values of the legacy currencies in the Eurozone, and establishes the value of the euro currency.
1999 – First President of Russia, Boris Yeltsin, resigns from office, leaving Prime Minister Vladimir Putin as the acting President and successor.
Events.text: First President of Russia, Boris Yeltsin, resigns from office, leaving Prime Minister Vladimir Putin as the acting President and successor.

Events.html: 1999 – The United States Government hands control of the Panama Canal (as well all the adjacent land to the canal known as the Panama Canal Zone) to Panama. This act complied with the signing of the 1977 Torrijos–Carter Treaties.
Events.text: The United States Government hands control of the Panama Canal (as well all the adjacent land to the canal known as the Panama Canal Zone) to Panama. This act complied with the signing of the 1977 Torrijos–Carter Treaties.

Events.html: 2004 – The official opening of Taipei 101, the tallest skyscraper at that time in the world, standing at a height of 509 metres (1,670 ft).
Events.text: The official opening of Taipei 101, the tallest skyscraper at that time in the world, standing at a height of 509 metres (1,670 ft).

links.subject: tallest
links.title: List of tallest buildings and structures in the world

Events.html: 2009 – Both a blue moon and a lunar eclipse occur.
Events.text: Both a blue moon and a lunar eclipse occur.

Events.html: 2010 – Tornadoes touch down in midwestern and southern United States, including Washington County, Arkansas; Greater St. Louis, Sunset Hills, Missouri, Illinois, and Oklahoma, with a few tornadoes in the early hours. A total 36 tornadoes touched down, resulting in the deaths of 9 people and $113 million in damages.
Events.text: Tornadoes touch down in midwestern and southern United States, including Washington County, Arkansas; Greater St. Louis, Sunset Hills, Missouri, Illinois, and Oklahoma, with a few tornadoes in the early hours. A total 36 tornadoes touched down, resulting in the deaths of 9 people and $113 million in damages.

Events.html: 2011 – NASA succeeds in putting the first of two Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory satellites in orbit around the moon.
Events.text: NASA succeeds in putting the first of two Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory satellites in orbit around the moon.
